awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Internet-Inspired Autonomous Electric Vehicle (EV) Charging
awd_abstract_narration:
Electric vehicles (EVs) are transforming the modern transportation and energy systems.  With a growing EV market, the mass penetration of EVs into the utility grid will result in detrimental effects due to coincidence between utility peak power loading and EV charging. This impact will include increased peak loading and voltage drops that will call for over-investments in the network resulting in an overall high cost for the society. Therefore, advanced and practical interaction methods between vehicles, charging stations, and the utility grid need to be developed. Internet-inspired EV charge control offers a new paradigm-shift for EV charge control studies. This  project aims to build a new  autonomous and fair EV charge control technique that can penetrate into practice at large scales. The significance of the proposed idea lies in the effort to bring together a cyber-physical system that utilizes the prior art in end-to-end internet network congestion control with decentralized autonomous EV charging. The effort is inter-disciplinary and brings together ideas from computer science as well as power engineering to support mass integration of EVs into the conventional electric energy system. The proposed idea can impact the way all grid-connected power electronics systems are controlled. The algorithms developed in this work can be used to accelerate the integration of low-carbon energy sources such as solar photovoltaic systems.     

The proposed research develops a new family of EV charging algorithms by adopting some of the well-deployed end-to-end congestion control techniques in the Internet. The research objectives include (i) investigating distribution grid congestion through extensive data collection from field, modeling, and simulations to understand and extract the impacts of EV charging on voltage and frequency signatures at the end-nodes, (ii) design of entirely decentralized and localized EV charging algorithms that work autonomously, (iii) investigation of adaptive increase and decrease of EV charging rate according to the power flow congestion on the distribution network to attain proportional or max-min fair charging of EVs in a neighborhood, and (iv) exploration of hybrid charging architectures where more than one EV measurement can be utilized. The cyber-physical system that will be developed with this project will help the researchers understand and resolve issues relating to large scale electric vehicle integration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
As the electrification of transportation gains speed, the concerns around the impacts of mass electric vehicle (EV) integration on the power distribution grid are rising. Most proposed solutions for controlling and coordinating the EV charging approach the problem from a centralized and model-based perspective. However, they usually suffer from impracticality, since they often require real-time communication and complete system knowledge. This project explored an Internet-inspired, data-driven, decentralized, model-free EV charging control algorithm that can dynamically monitor the power system's congestion via local measurements and take actions to reduce it without needing real-time central feedback.

The scientific merit of the project centered around exploring the relationship between the residential end-node voltage and total substation power demand in a distribution network so that a distributed congestion detection mechanism could be derived. A machine learning (ML) method is investigated to estimate the model parameters using historical measurements. In addition, the developed ML model is integrated into the proposed EV charging controller as a feedback mechanism. The proposed controller structure is the Additive Increase and Multiplicative Decrease (AIMD) algorithm, which is heavily used in Internet and adapted to the EV charging problem. The developed ideas and charging algorithms were tested under various case studies. The proposed algorithm effectively eliminated the grid congestion, utilized the available system capacity, and established fairness among EV customers. Besides, the algorithm is practical and easy to implement on an actual EV. To support this claim, the study demonstrated the developed charging controller in a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) environment featuring an actual EV. The designed hardware testbed was used to implement the proposed AIMD-based EV charging controller on the EV under different scenarios. The results showed that the proposed controller adjusted the EV's charging current based on the grid's congestion level confirming the simulation studies.

The broader impact of the effort is very large. The proposed end-to-end EV charging techniques can revolutionize the way all power electronics-based systems interact with the power grid. The standards and protocols produced from this project can significantly impact the utility, EV, and EV supply equipment market at large. The society will benefit from fully utilizing the available infrastructure capacity which will reduce the economic burden of hosting more EVs in a distribution system. The algorithms and protocols developed in this work can be used to accelerate the integration of low-carbon, inexpensive energy sources such as Wind and Solar into the electric grid. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in power electronics, electric vehicles, and power distribution grid research areas and resulted in doctoral and master?s degrees.  


Last Modified: 01/14/2023
Modified by: Mithat J Kisacikoglu
